title: Gin
ingredients: 3 oz. gin; 1/2 oz. dry vermouth; green olive or lemon twist, for garnish
howtouse: Stir gin and vermouth in a mixing glass with ice for about twenty seconds. Strain into a chilled martini glass.
note: A classic – always stirred, never shaken.
tip: If you like a wetter martini, try a 4:1 ratio of gin to vermouth instead of our suggested 6:1 ratio. If you're no fan of vermouth, keep stepping it back until that bottle has fully exited the kitchen, à la Winston Churchill, who famously said he drank martinis with only gin and a bow in the direction of France. Our suggestions: Halcyon Organic Distilled Gin, Walla Walla Gin or Spy Hop.

title: Gin
howtouse: Add three dashes of Angostura bitters to a chilled rocks glass and swirl to coat the bottom. Pour off the excess and then add gin.
note: A British cocktail that's stiffer than it looks.
tip: If it's too strong, add a large ice cube and top off with soda water. Our suggestions: Big Gin or Counter Gin (sub in orange bitters with a splash of soda, says Batch 206 owner Jeff Steichen).

title: Gin
ingredients: 3/4 oz. gin; 3/4 oz. lime juice; 3/4 oz. green Chartreuse; 3/4 oz. maraschino liqueur
howtouse: Shake gin, lime juice, green Chartreuse and maraschino liqueur with ice, then strain into a cocktail glass.
note: A once-forgotten cocktail that was resurrected by Seattle bartender Murray Stenson.
tip: Try this with a London dry-style gin. Our suggestions: Voyager or Big Gin.
source: Recipe from "The Essential Bartender's Guide" by Robert Hess.

title: Gin
ingredients: 1 oz. gin; 1 oz. Campari; 1 oz. sweet vermouth; orange twist, for garnish
howtouse: Stir gin, Campari and sweet vermouth in a mixing glass with ice. Strain into a coupe glass.
note: A cocktail that's moodily spicy and sweet, but not always to everyone's taste.
tip: For a drier version, try a 3:1:1 ratio of gin to Campari and vermouth. Our suggestion: Copperworks Gin.

title: Accoutrements
ingredients: 1 1/2 oz. gin; 3/4 oz. lime juice; 3/4 oz. simple syrup; 8-10 mint leaves; 2 oz. Rachel's ginger beer
howtouse: Muddle the mint leaves with lime juice and simple syrup in the bottom of a mixing glass or shaker. Add gin and ice. Shake well, then strain into a highball glass filled with ice and top with ginger beer.
note: A sweet, mint-flecked cocktail created by New York mixologist Audrey Saunders.
tip: This adaptation is from Copperworks, and works well with their robust gin.

title: Whiskey

note: A steamy cocktail to help ward away winter's flus.
